_dÝ¡§¿ôh¡4&ð+Xai¾F=ÓµBêá^<}3Â~*àf¼®CéÎÉÚ#£e0ÈVu¦Z¡â3÷>¬&øMËTr3l$=_~µGØÉÈz½³ºZ£Ìz½ó·"d>¤'F¡6!#Xçá22MÉº¥ñ¶¤q~µ&ôBa¿àl£rÿ␀"þ¾aí£ÀÕh!4$(kXM!ÿÚ␀␀␀␀␀␀÷Äy}}÷ß_ëï¾ûï¾␀Uè½÷ß}öÎÿ␀ûï¾IÀp2÷ß}÷ß}{o¾î@wß}÷ß}÷Û>H_5@C}÷ß}÷ß}ÏB²`␀¶Ãß}÷ß}ñ.)ù␀␀␀bOnt`-@␀␀␀␀␀␀G®lÝ~8q␀␀␀␀	´é¦'úðA.(°Â{ïcg
1Î8°Õ÷°Þ/v{æÚ¼Û}Hã¾à\wÇ	à	øuà ÿÄ␀'␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀!1AQ 0a±q¡ÁÑðñÿÚ␀?Âº°Ä?P±EÄ MÇ4Áë8séweÈø~b#ºÑuìèY×CÉùÚM}¡H½A67øæY%AÄeí®%Îócyíd9ZdögsA¶ÊslA9¼¬¶Zq°³þËûìá<b`mlï¹S¯ïÑ>Æ >×¦Ê~ÿ␀Á.?¤	±áäù8°x8ÜñãþÃhZëÂ}G{bÀqäçëli9u¦N}zùÊº.g¼¶»/ñ-§cÎÂ5ñ°°°°±øØÈ.N?d-;ÃcbGÁÓÑ(¸I*Éð¸q;,ö»¹ÿ␀|I
K jvV%ÝYe-ÿÄ␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀! 01a@QÿÚ␀?ã-,÷,£xOà[Ôõîx}ÄG¿ëÈ8	ÙwfyÏidð<å§␀©$³óË,³ P×Rã&Ëñ ê<e¢ì»ÝÉìGöxyË<ò"jË3ÂxåYàE±s²Ë,²Ë,²È%úq¯ìIe2Ë,eYÀÃ'N2␀äEu%A9,YÿÄ␀%␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀!1 AQa0@q¡ðÁÑÿÚ␀␀?è	XæQä©_P2.9K%8KùjWÑ
èÐYtª¯po8e/ç©_(W@ï
°á±ØÕÆWxòÇNRþDøºþcV¬Ú2ÙuïÐF¥|bðs9KèlÞÉÍÝÇ
z¾JzÂÞï{þæñãã¬¿Z¥9 Q"WôÙpn=ò/¡/ìÈ@¶3? Ð E¶ç(óOB_×òÞvË{uÝÙçòt¥Ä¯®nÈ[zÿ␀ÙÍÌ&G~¤õÎGxÓÞßòsÀ§	_u*T§ç	Ry`§AÍÿ␀Äq+	¯R¥J~½®,æT _¸GF bøq/Ò¢T©N$
SBFEÖËÔU¨ÍÁ­Íw7>Òlô\Z ­X£Ë(rmg(¸õH©Øò1Ö÷4$­±¶*hâ-½wÜ8C«|héÐv+`vî_Ô©µÑDSzQ>Áç8#Ð²ûËðvæÚ4·eØSëqÇ·ñ-óÚ&
®hdçcËêAú\ íBÏháTnÚÊw4\¾|KûV8Ø¾aÕYÜ<¹N´¸øD¯¸N`ÅºRébß·¬V,]\xÀÝô%|(ÓNêç²hT¿Qàºþç'3BWBWÇD£Ä£ÇÀåÉ»ªªwsû;°ó9ôý Éïaà²(X);ä£¨ó|¥e.(é©R¥R¥J*T©D£ À `d¸Åx"DÂWæRºp´§Ç]\´´§ÇP,␀ÀA¹{àææP&Ã!Ä;9¼î&b±D©D¨«fËþbf[␀1c␀(%Û}âTKÂØ␀d0`ÜEm^¡¨EÖøº^»* îR"Kj£5¸ã)c )4âP7
¥¥½qþ©²>¥JÒzAªîZ£ÍÍ½JÂ¡ÿÙ
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        51. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/2.jpg&size=160
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (310 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/2.jpg&size=160 HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?cat=1
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (186 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2022 13:37:46 GMT
Content-Type: image/jpeg
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (3324 bytes)

!t␀)ò4(ÜþÏï´p\¸MâVåäïAÐ9®î	6äÓµ;4Íø§ju8NÍ$-¼ìíQ¸íÝbòA©Í^)ñ×ã²ÐÞ;ÿÄ␀&␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀! 0A#1"CaÿÚ␀?ÚÉKdeeùY~÷ÔI(´b­ô_¡³S\{1ª]eé²üÌï¢×c{6j"ÛéºB÷ílÍmª#ºÞËô¹ör­òDd)

z¾JzÂÞï{þæñãã¬¿Z¥9 Q"WôÙpn=ò/¡/ìÈ@¶3? Ð E¶ç(óOB_×òÞvË{uÝÙçòt¥Ä¯®nÈ[zÿ␀ÙÍÌ&G~¤õÎGxÓÞßòsÀ§	_u*T§ç	Ry`§AÍÿ␀Äq+	¯R¥J~½®,æT _¸GF bøq/Ò¢T©N$
SBFEÖËÔU¨ÍÁ­Íw7>Òlô\Z ­X£Ë(rmg(¸õH©Øò1Ö÷4$­±¶*hâ-½wÜ8C«|héÐv+`vî_Ô©µÑDSzQ>Áç8#Ð²ûËðvæÚ4·eØSëqÇ·ñ-óÚ&
®hdçcËêAú\ íBÏháTnÚÊw4\¾|KûV8Ø¾aÕYÜ<¹N´¸øD¯¸N`ÅºRébß·¬V,]\xÀÝô%|(ÓNêç²hT¿Qàºþç'3BWBWÇD£Ä£ÇÀåÉ»ªªwsû;°ó9ôý Éïaà²(X);ä£¨ó|¥e.(é©R¥R¥J*T©D£ À `d¸Åx"DÂWæRºp´§Ç]\´´§ÇP,␀ÀA¹{àææP&Ã!Ä;9¼î&b±D©D¨«fËþbf[␀1c␀(%Û}âTKÂØ␀d0`ÜEm^¡¨EÖøº^»* îR"Kj£5¸ã)c )4âP7
¥¥½qþ©²>¥JÒzAªîZ£ÍÍ½JÂ¡ÿÙ
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        52. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/3.jpg
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (301 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/3.jpg HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?cat=1
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (186 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0

Content-Type: image/jpeg
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (9692 bytes) 
          ÿØÿà␀JFIF␀␀␀␀␀␀ÿÛ␀C␀


		
%# , #&')*)-0-(0%()(ÿÛ␀C

¸éjâ©
Ñbi·ÛuT=¡[?	>ôxÈññÁÃ)·â1C5Ø?¼51Ø_`­»#¶%p4Þê␀X0JlÀà)Å␀ÕònÌÿ␀§QAS¦#¥ºßÀÇÁQ¡}¢láåÒ%¡¤	hyZDØ¥§"*bô¤vPv>cõ÷(Òx}8FNE!A+¹¤)Ò`^È :%=+>]?k¼§ëåk¼@pêÀ<ÍÆúqv0àÆ{OxgÃUI«Fj^MFËçxô=fè$SnÍä¬
¦L-¨ZT §mþÐÎaö©>9~9Ç9¸Êx¢A9PCXrÜÑ¤t×þwÆNÇBÎ`¨4
nRAm␀°¤	w®i<9NBV ÓãÐ0ËAîÔy´äf¨XÚoMtÑ2coXïj!Ð»úÄÚÐGJoO^sKo␀¢y)o`ÜA+?Çû¼H#`M¶¼3töu_ÅÄ¤ÁÓXZ°¨Î öÛX9␀UBóÜTåRDbuÎq·©¯­¤©A±ðÐËcGcS¼4º+ûf$÷␀®¿£x1$£Dpñ0^ð)cQDP5f¬ÀÁD ;VåÒUú¬$␀,:M_È`;ÑM␀ëYKFIúDé(5ø©LDÄsÁ³?ÕË!ÓÙ#Vuµ½,ÙhåÅ¿␀°K¹)ØE#ë'Ïõðõ2Ï

	ÄûXx2<êÉ÷¶/9>°¬0n/y¥×Y¶cÁ.kXÄcÃëieh4¥£Ï(QD§Oã4¡AÇ-¦#8ú p¤Å
b×␀]Îl±RoæL?!ÃØëIù3jqPíZExÇf"}ô=cââ''Ê>Câ XBZçLAç r[¯®ÓA7äÙ0Ïxà&Ü&ãA/J§°¦}0 ¥␀bi=9¹~³õÅ¤Î³ª[bA!+|* _áCÁð}KadjÆ:ªBóE  ¹Ð°¾
ëÛåÁdNZP␀$IYU<àâúÖyøåügÕÊ"Êù1AÜiRJ¶ õÞrùyaqk~ jxÂba¼øá]ÑÙêJDv&ÎZ:ÓlLSúÅÛú1ÀôX@Yí×)ÎQ¤«È4ðc¼yùyüeò¯¦Ø

Qra*h*(râÙ4H␀ãA/I]ñ¶þ~Uq'Ðø8£ðgÐë)ÇÃ5A¨Ñ =T8m6ÆÃÌ]8WMC␀òæS§t¢£Ñ*c²¤ð
ªð ¥y°:ÁÚ}a$p
Öáö|c
!òZÒS@ÊÁwàhéCNßlÞ¾­	"@w»»3içR`£ëÈxÇÃ?ÿÙ
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        53. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/3.jpg&size=160
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (310 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/3.jpg&size=160 HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?cat=1
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (186 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2022 13:37:46 GMT
Content-Type: image/jpeg
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (9692 bytes) 
          ÿØÿà␀JFIF␀␀␀␀␀␀ÿÛ␀C␀

V ñþIªÀøWüÃbðuööýàXR* `3©R4'P PÖSr=`TèúÄE|$_"XJ%gLCätÿ␀ÿÄ␀*␀␀␀␀␀␀␀!1AQaq ¡ð0@±ÁÑñáPÿÚ␀␀?!ÿ␀È²M°Ú?§¤Ç¶/Î¸9h¶>Fx?AûEF[³À´!uö¦º]y¢	Ò¬"»w'␀ç:ûhÞ,Y:«·2°7O¹}h&ÿ␀ÃCkzl´æ Iÿ␀?åMº	zÉ␀[XóPRË"àÙú8$sr?Ö&Yjñ¼y¿-Og°÷úqö/näÓÙÃ M±¿XqcuÃÇo4qE)Î¿¾áK\Û	Ýß ÄÖØ>Z6ÖÞÜ	pT␀:üBC\~êÚÃµyRq~«êM@ÞòB=êä,ÜYKãõPL8X÷mV Av¦úi§½¾ÖÁ2Î	DI{ÌAóY"*b]'{eÿ␀"YrÛþkVªtÍ*ÁN-ùßJ´[Íã=·èÖÏØ~ißÕÈò>;ÐáÂmÆ>ê3MÌ Nç:.

nRAm␀°¤	w®i<9NBV ÓãÐ0ËAîÔy´äf¨XÚoMtÑ2coXïj!Ð»úÄÚÐGJoO^sKo␀¢y)o`ÜA+?Çû¼H#`M¶¼3töu_ÅÄ¤ÁÓXZ°¨Î öÛX9␀UBóÜTåRDbuÎq·©¯­¤©A±ðÐËcGcS¼4º+ûf$÷␀®¿£x1$£Dpñ0^ð)cQDP5f¬ÀÁD ;VåÒUú¬$␀,:M_È`;ÑM␀ëYKFIúDé(5ø©LDÄsÁ³?ÕË!ÓÙ#Vuµ½,ÙhåÅ¿␀°K¹)ØE#ë'Ïõðõ2Ï

	ÄûXx2<êÉ÷¶/9>°¬0n/y¥×Y¶cÁ.kXÄcÃëieh4¥£Ï(QD§Oã4¡AÇ-¦#8ú p¤Å

ëÛåÁdNZP␀$IYU<àâúÖyøåügÕÊ"Êù1AÜiRJ¶ õÞrùyaqk~ jxÂba¼øá]ÑÙêJDv&ÎZ:ÓlLSúÅÛú1ÀôX@Yí×)ÎQ¤«È4ðc¼yùyüeò¯¦Ø

Qra*h*(râÙ4H␀ãA/I]ñ¶þ~Uq'Ðø8£ðgÐë)ÇÃ5A¨Ñ =T8m6ÆÃÌ]8WMC␀òæS§t¢£Ñ*c²¤ð
ªð ¥y°:ÁÚ}a$p
Öáö|c
!òZÒS@ÊÁwàhéCNßlÞ¾­	"@w»»3içR`£ëÈxÇÃ?ÿÙ
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        54. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/4.jpg
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (301 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/4.jpg HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?cat=1
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (186 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2022 13:37:45 GMT
Content-Type: image/jpeg
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (13969 bytes) 
          ÿØÿà␀JFIF␀␀␀␀␀␀ÿÛ␀C␀





(((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((ÿÂ␀␀È@"␀ÿÄ␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀ÿÄ␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀ÿÚ␀␀␀␀{ÅÞá¥{æ\Óbð78öJÙ×ªH*HùÖrÏµËéòVÙY1rÉ;¸ô5Ly0×°f× jâ6)Ô#³¤è4hÕvbRÒÞ·=òÚIv.s®No+­Æ½)`©(u¡º»IR;âôyÓ¿^©ðv) ©Óê­-¬j n(ñsäJS¶u^¡5&fÌfÈI4¶=ùåÜgôS¤±Õ#,ös%~¶ ©ÎäK£¥µeyÓ©kî4î¼ìç³µ}Yèy¹Þ«ñæÙÈU@è¶ÍM¸XÊf!ÞCÓOhxnWbK¶Ë­]ÐX]ë2%ct4µ¼ÐÄ£Ä$i/«=`ö ©¼õ{®ÂºzB×µlÜa¬½
[íY·°ékã|êÒZ&;åKu
;³¹A;Q1ÎméÒLª·IZ5F[å4 tN¦¼ÚÄ8@òx]¾RÍì'§~]ÄaØªÃÎú:°<#,,ÐÇ¶yÙØ+°EÈÀiÛcÅFÙSåÕ!LãvfëSmÊæ tkÍég!JýÀó@:5aËYì¼nÌÜ§¢dA£Þæ|íqõÎQE/yß;ë7¨Wkf2àèº&LS¯:]ëÏvsÛåÑKOU®Ô¶µç§ihÀH´X	¡'=ù¤Õ¦ª¤G©xYGÔíôû¼¾2CÅ´æ£Á¶õÈè[íÎ×%´æsRÆÚî=³´i`8Ô`ãK³íg6¡n{ò è¨ì*,Ìæ¹Õ!ðuz¿ióJ|î»üÍ¼ÛªÈ5èðcÞØ9ö§cRnÓÙÆÚVfÝ&Ñg'7;.âzFùK·=<½z3ãfçl¹d§}sªZÌ§¯ËJuæ½

uÿÚ␀␀␀␀␀␀©¼Å·×Ýðz¥¢àu¿ªawdÒøCÉþ&!ôý@6ßMí[T¬D#ÄÅ¥KUÅ;Ð×âBò´fbTÙ5ÚþÂj¼·KÞMÈÖáõc©A Ó*OÙmW°úÁ²Q*Cë­¸¥iÅñdªýRq¸aÆ%ÑâòY´MÍ¤¶FÚóð÷IÄ£%ÍPQæbàwùZæãCd'Ð©u2ñÿ␀B|~?]÷ùÿ␀<ÿÄ␀(␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀!1AQð aq¡±Á0ÑáñÿÚ␀?ÿ␀Ø)Oe®zãã¯³,_ÏUm­ù-␀~#Z*+%À9õ¿␀Ï¾ÏNqo,h]ïëÉce0ELîûÔ·^S¯ÌøQPÔ¸<_YÙ<TBLÅàþüøçPú´aÃ¦Qh!ÉÓ®&9Ñá©ÖÃ¼÷ß¾`]D¢â0ú´Ðjb®ÉYzCÍÆbßÖæ)Qúãñ<¼Ó=ñë3sÞûô\Fûâ␀1UÒG=bs	ùI ôÖ¾ø'ÖuE/Á¤&ràqññ.Xâ©Éï[eã±Wí¦DÃI{uZ76µ¤"°+½âô¯û¿â;ø4ÌÇeïÙ¯#Pjá/¾øûEüWñõæêV×HpÊ?Á6Ô^h8vþ~~¥¯Lýw¾Ø_Ìæ3u_ÜGß¶¢␀¼ê:FIW¨*¹¾ß´3¡Å±ÌñÁ)Ý_ÌO{'¼³Åm7eÈ©òÚW¸dêdh¬þ%ée`h¤míWîzCU(Äòì·£öK¨&Ïxj¹ÔÈzLßj]³L«m]ÿ␀ÏMBË¿©|á¯Wý~E9<øÆð~Á,TÈ³¶pD: WÐxFDë_°9.

ê«và␀x0J¡;;|y0{Õxï 99,WÖ*ZÎÊlá»×Ky'­ýfVût:?\Þd#}öuÎmÀ␀G0␀,XÂ2bõ5AØ;{ø×ïX<ÆÏ§ü·@`ð`$ó;áÀ,{s±ÎçÐ0wà½á_õ}`óñ
e>4}Bñ¨3èÐU@tEÐYýÝmI}ùÁâ=ÝHm␀␀HÀ1òÄ ¤Sm¦Õ4kÉ`^4~°ËÖ=þÉR"+8¦¡@(åxÄuHÙÓëG8ÞüóÕ¡¸Ô£78ß'xÀC»Þùÿ␀_XX»ûÃ198¡xJsLh !èþÿ␀<`[æÍÄüE_Õ=]ïÛÞh5H­ÿ␀8hõÇ1_p|gg]¹G|ùb-`ðOðFÑî}dç4cTg8§T-jÞyjqö.µ¼4¢6FÎ9ýf¥v¼¯xÀL°¼éßêjåm1ªÝÝ¥Õ^/É7Çëj@
ûk¦óÍ3h$GV¼­#z	'÷ÆP³A÷=fÆÃ÷èTxf ¢u³§àìáÀáh@W\
ñL
Ò±ÏÑ␀ôÂNu'f:1Ñß8(úüS0␀Öà{ÄÒÔ<RAõÉÙáÆ¨è»­¨¥ò]%m␀È␀=` ¼Ñÿ␀]äUÞDÞ=|+23tÙiÏØºÒVÓj·Nþr]Ê ªul%Ã,~K2¼G<␀w.ç'¼5é?Þÿ␀y³UÊÀz=â¦T%'p¿x/b(µ´gòg]Hü)P×Kå)ÿ␀p¢¡¨ú%×ß<cÀ-iaRÈ:áÞûÂã§&<p|þ@¬ü

Ã!¿CËï$53èÊ¥ÑYÃ~ú&hæÙà.mÖ:B,½½òäÖÊvÕ÷¿åÎ8´Òüõ

Ã}ÃèÅ§ÜtÃ§MÑù"D@DDËÚxãvQcH)ºðèãÈøØ¶ÁzÞ°³  Ñ2»ìÅJ`Ðàëða5³5·XÏN¸§÷ï␀àÈð!!ÏbG
¬ÐH60j
ï{þ;ÃL¯0␀
÷ëö[ÂNFq(w¹,D¬  Ãüå?yN6'#ëUÛ²$¼¾tÍñÍT _ï<lË8(	ïúÄ<Ï¬nãé­ÌÔWR2½¿­\Ð?Xu«4¼"ÔIKp± Bhõ®Ânö<?§Si␀>5ÞðüëgQÌr~?ÿÙ
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        55. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/4.jpg&size=160
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (310 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/4.jpg&size=160 HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?cat=1
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (186 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0

uÿÚ␀␀␀␀␀␀©¼Å·×Ýðz¥¢àu¿ªawdÒøCÉþ&!ôý@6ßMí[T¬D#ÄÅ¥KUÅ;Ð×âBò´fbTÙ5ÚþÂj¼·KÞMÈÖáõc©A Ó*OÙmW°úÁ²Q*Cë­¸¥iÅñdªýRq¸aÆ%ÑâòY´MÍ¤¶FÚóð÷IÄ£%ÍPQæbàwùZæãCd'Ð©u2ñÿ␀B|~?]÷ùÿ␀<ÿÄ␀(␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀!1AQð aq¡±Á0ÑáñÿÚ␀?ÿ␀Ø)Oe®zãã¯³,_ÏUm­ù-␀~#Z*+%À9õ¿␀Ï¾ÏNqo,h]ïëÉce0ELîûÔ·^S¯ÌøQPÔ¸<_YÙ<TBLÅàþüøçPú´aÃ¦Qh!ÉÓ®&9Ñá©ÖÃ¼÷ß¾`]D¢â0ú´Ðjb®ÉYzCÍÆbßÖæ)Qúãñ<¼Ó=ñë3sÞûô\Fûâ␀1UÒG=bs	ùI ôÖ¾ø'ÖuE/Á¤&ràqññ.Xâ©Éï[eã±Wí¦DÃI{uZ76µ¤"°+½âô¯û¿â;ø4ÌÇeïÙ¯#Pjá/¾øûEüWñõæêV×HpÊ?Á6Ô^h8vþ~~¥¯Lýw¾Ø_Ìæ3u_ÜGß¶¢␀¼ê:FIW¨*¹¾ß´3¡Å±ÌñÁ)Ý_ÌO{'¼³Åm7eÈ©òÚW¸dêdh¬þ%ée`h¤míWîzCU(Äòì·£öK¨&Ïxj¹ÔÈzLßj]³L«m]ÿ␀ÏMBË¿©|á¯Wý~E9<øÆð~Á,TÈ³¶pD: WÐxFDë_°9.

ê«và␀x0J¡;;|y0{Õxï 99,WÖ*ZÎÊlá»×Ky'­ýfVût:?\Þd#}öuÎmÀ␀G0␀,XÂ2bõ5AØ;{ø×ïX<ÆÏ§ü·@`ð`$ó;áÀ,{s±ÎçÐ0wà½á_õ}`óñ
e>4}Bñ¨3èÐU@tEÐYýÝmI}ùÁâ=ÝHm␀␀HÀ1òÄ ¤Sm¦Õ4kÉ`^4~°ËÖ=þÉR"+8¦¡@(åxÄuHÙÓëG8ÞüóÕ¡¸Ô£78ß'xÀC»Þùÿ␀_XX»ûÃ198¡xJsLh !èþÿ␀<`[æÍÄüE_Õ=]ïÛÞh5H­ÿ␀8hõÇ1_p|gg]¹G|ùb-`ðOðFÑî}dç4cTg8§T-jÞyjqö.µ¼4¢6FÎ9ýf¥v¼¯xÀL°¼éßêjåm1ªÝÝ¥Õ^/É7Çëj@
ûk¦óÍ3h$GV¼­#z	'÷ÆP³A÷=fÆÃ÷èTxf ¢u³§àìáÀáh@W\
ñL
Ò±ÏÑ␀ôÂNu'f:1Ñß8(úüS0␀Öà{ÄÒÔ<RAõÉÙáÆ¨è»­¨¥ò]%m␀È␀=` ¼Ñÿ␀]äUÞDÞ=|+23tÙiÏØºÒVÓj·Nþr]Ê ªul%Ã,~K2¼G<␀w.ç'¼5é?Þÿ␀y³UÊÀz=â¦T%'p¿x/b(µ´gòg]Hü)P×Kå)ÿ␀p¢¡¨ú%×ß<cÀ-iaRÈ:áÞûÂã§&<p|þ@¬ü

Ã!¿CËï$53èÊ¥ÑYÃ~ú&hæÙà.mÖ:B,½½òäÖÊvÕ÷¿åÎ8´Òüõ

Ã}ÃèÅ§ÜtÃ§MÑù"D@DDËÚxãvQcH)ºðèãÈøØ¶ÁzÞ°³  Ñ2»ìÅJ`Ðàëða5³5·XÏN¸§÷ï␀àÈð!!ÏbG
¬ÐH60j
ï{þ;ÃL¯0␀
÷ëö[ÂNFq(w¹,D¬  Ãüå?yN6'#ëUÛ²$¼¾tÍñÍT _ï<lË8(	ïúÄ<Ï¬nãé­ÌÔWR2½¿­\Ð?Xu«4¼"ÔIKp± Bhõ®Ânö<?§Si␀>5ÞðüëgQÌr~?ÿÙ
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        56. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/5.jpg
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (301 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/5.jpg HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?cat=1
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (186 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0

ÔJ-Z8YúÝkÊ-<´4xçëÏr£Õ7	JóÂo␀²`j0*¿[õ|ñÿ␀óU¯Î#ÞSÞÂbXF:Ü]9ECuõuÜÕ=ñfÇÆÏº c¡%ã[ÆÙK©¨0ôA$Ñ'ë 3p Tíò.·IÊbnñÓã$!Õ½CK¨Ôde`ÚzÌBi4Fíßµæ\®\®8ë5íYú |®ð

@lGM¾1âûÈÏ§à&!*8¬O´Q×E8SíNÑ}[/5xÉªó×&85)HÇOiòo4b$nÎëYµC4Wéòw~DW¸áWò3Ö:E10Uã§|Gab␀Py´aÞöc
Ô?5<QMÓ;SOïí<ò±×oUì÷OfÊd␀[½0ç1ª´ú1Õ]þ)Ê{Êåq~r?ÈS°£ Q)8`$øÖ7ûË/æ¸8å<<pÜ¥8u0RînÎIÝæ¢á@<âî␀AOXUËþJeÊåråråË+ü)÷ø®\\§¿ÁX·üéË+üª~üëï+ïü®S.Wùiï#>YY_Íråÿ␀ÿÙ
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        57. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/5.jpg&size=160
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (310 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/5.jpg&size=160 HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?cat=1
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (186 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2022 13:37:46 GMT
Content-Type: image/jpeg
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (14228 bytes) 
          ÿØÿà␀JFIF␀␀␀␀␀␀ÿÛ␀C␀

-Æûs5£±¡­8m=ëïCnºµ3ÄÖ®|Kn`BÑn82¢Ú/båHÑWyô={ARòjvÂF¨£GGYÞîßJ0YV­®îzvçÕ_C®ÓÃõ.¡	³°Ëåoç¼%àñÛ÷T;Jk3HÅÏ	´|ÅNùc"{?D$]ÈºVN°áiA}n{WÃ¶[ëÞXK_¾ãgÐ;{¹+æ'¬ÒÞk2/\

ÔJ-Z8YúÝkÊ-<´4xçëÏr£Õ7	JóÂo␀²`j0*¿[õ|ñÿ␀óU¯Î#ÞSÞÂbXF:Ü]9ECuõuÜÕ=ñfÇÆÏº c¡%ã[ÆÙK©¨0ôA$Ñ'ë 3p Tíò.·IÊbnñÓã$!Õ½CK¨Ôde`ÚzÌBi4Fíßµæ\®\®8ë5íYú |®ð

@lGM¾1âûÈÏ§à&!*8¬O´Q×E8SíNÑ}[/5xÉªó×&85)HÇOiòo4b$nÎëYµC4Wéòw~DW¸áWò3Ö:E10Uã§|Gab␀Py´aÞöc
Ô?5<QMÓ;SOïí<ò±×oUì÷OfÊd␀[½0ç1ª´ú1Õ]þ)Ê{Êåq~r?ÈS°£ Q)8`$øÖ7ûË/æ¸8å<<pÜ¥8u0RînÎIÝæ¢á@<âî␀AOXUËþJeÊåråråË+ü)÷ø®\\§¿ÁX·üéË+üª~üëï+ïü®S.Wùiï#>YY_Íråÿ␀ÿÙ
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        58. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/6.jpg
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (301 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/6.jpg HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?cat=2
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (186 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2022 13:37:46 GMT
Content-Type: image/jpeg
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (11465 bytes)

*hç)>¸¥7ygr8ìÆ␀ð\÷AÓé:¸gÆ^ÓÁùN>­í·>§ÈdD¯K3Ú"5yÒÑÐéq5ÙD ©­×fÍ¤kO.[/ûÀ1ÆDU×0tjÞ?_¾-%$+¥2ñÄpõ¯òu8Ý~N±^öK­ÐnV#½	'¥Å:aè"vc8Å{:Q®0±°½§½ððíø¦þ_Ö?\xc£Cföö£4{ÄTc(Ç¬BÓ_°ò÷ë¥y<!ºy23y´$ØZ{Õ¡¢c÷\Jè©6jr
5£þÑ®§Ù,%ÓUy×Ëµ«|M[Ûiüâ®jõ)§àßÕÄ ½éDù³Õeo³|vþs2vT)µäª,Óéw!þ95ìw÷G>Ì"YBE£rù5Õü	
)Ý·É:{BÉH)ðÒ{1_ò¨␀]ÎO¨§×u¼³|&ó]ëYNÈùÊeªSáxbðèª³¡iD£ñÎôI<ø>¡ÆuÙ8û¸.°Ì3IØ7%.F»^³$DÙi) R¨(&êÁÆÔ©Uá¨6û8»gÑäÎ%(ûñÇ(vº¦Z]xçðI¯5¿¹xéãMÒà	½nç␀³gî}Mý2#ÓÀ;ºÕà `K	FÄ{x.ªTç­Hûüw[ÉõÁA,LÙIðÇñ1Ø<¯ÎT¸Ò#^¿Î*ªlr*WË-?#´æ;:¸48ÃfQXOO¼WÓ°¹?½L`"%`8+âßY-Ôìår>FaÎBJÝuÄÁ®
èl÷þÕ¨µþ&H¤äjÂº`Ûûñí`¨`y␀MñX-ãõÏbÿ␀»␀!¡AÀ¨aÆä\"Ò1À2tññõ9$¯IÁ ß6\JIýÆzL-¤4ë ðµ®B­:gXBð=sý÷GéV¥.Î>q¢ìÅ>áÖÓCåÖöªÖ÷û]¯É¼@¥ÀÆA;®`U]
ÛYdß!D!eàâ.¿ùGCõþk=xÎ␀5rAübòõÇÔ$Êä	ª9kr¨çoßùÊÎOyð[Þ"X¯üï¼tc©ÕtøçÕQ¬\^XÓ°Û³¿¶)ÊPý&
±F©ïÃüà^ÜMtÊ³gÇ¨6¯Ýûäm'gå5E<TFÉS-àì Zðý1ëpÃúùÃ¥×ú8Á
=lä¶.ÝðhØxÀÈÑ'¬}!7¬1%z®äSæ¼l+â*¼Â¶Dqµµð8ã¶`mGef¢l"'©®NúpØÃÉámà§aåØâ¡üfò¨n´³n_çxÑL4␀×è

1dÎYBz9>R¯6çgõÄáhlnpßE^Z»:N¿''yÍèó6Öâ7÷1Ã`'NÃÛôÄÕJá¾þ¿¦H

cB]]Ý␀Ó¦¢x1p*µ;aè8 måØý.ÀBñG7ÇR'YiË½»À(G?Ö*ÃÔg,ªâõ§¼Á ©×ÆYÒ8|:ÍA¨¶Y/`¡¶þN5H¯Z0ÂT<¦ò"/Aê;C¡Ò␀{ûúÁ"`5CÎirzæ␀öÌ£SFÏ~Æé $'ÑÏvñÂyuña°k þ¦	ê¢ÉÓGýçÖi+i»­÷ò~ÙÖí
 À(Àd¿oü0	3Iáðñª¡«¢;Ou¹		_F¸ºÞøÁK'-^8¯+ÿ␀Ièrøç¼ìPÙk>Çÿ␀Íä¦b l  ìY_Èÿ␀ÿÙ
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        59. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/6.jpg&size=160
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (310 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/6.jpg&size=160 HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?cat=2
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (186 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2022 13:37:47 GMT
Content-Type: image/jpeg
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (11465 bytes) 
          ÿØÿà␀JFIF␀␀␀␀␀␀ÿÛ␀C␀


		
%# , #&')*)-0-(0%()(ÿÛ␀C



(((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((ÿÂ␀␀È@"␀ÿÄ␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀ÿÄ␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀ÿÚ␀␀␀␀å ␀␀␀␀␀¬×5æê{¬N=yT_S$␀␀␀␀␀␀␀¢Õ+kËô¨¼\±ÒnriËýÛfë	fy»[._&º~vÇõåÉY,o¯Ì␀␀␀␀␀␀␀îËççÅØün­3Lí¸KÇ/÷¬ÂÞ'XÅ­¸{XÛ"Jjo
±xÜÕ£h½ûÜ¡Ý␀␀␀␀␀ùs:Ç¼ÛtÌ^ó6ÇÍ³åÒý¹~ñÓ-F··o%T K¯Ú#ù:ÔVÝI,dcYGúYï¯HôÜ¡"õ␀␀␀ê;G

5£þÑ®§Ù,%ÓUy×Ëµ«|M[Ûiüâ®jõ)§àßÕÄ ½éDù³Õeo³|vþs2vT)µäª,Óéw!þ95ìw÷G>Ì"YBE£rù5Õü	
)Ý·É:{BÉH)ðÒ{1_ò¨␀]ÎO¨§×u¼³|&ó]ëYNÈùÊeªSáxbðèª³¡iD£ñÎôI<ø>¡ÆuÙ8û¸.°Ì3IØ7%.F»^³$DÙi) R¨(&êÁÆÔ©Uá¨6û8»gÑäÎ%(ûñÇ(vº¦Z]xçðI¯5¿¹xéãMÒà	½nç␀³gî}Mý2#ÓÀ;ºÕà `K	FÄ{x.ªTç­Hûüw[ÉõÁA,LÙIðÇñ1Ø<¯ÎT¸Ò#^¿Î*ªlr*WË-?#´æ;:¸48ÃfQXOO¼WÓ°¹?½L`"%`8+âßY-Ôìår>FaÎBJÝuÄÁ®
èl÷þÕ¨µþ&H¤äjÂº`Ûûñí`¨`y␀MñX-ãõÏbÿ␀»␀!¡AÀ¨aÆä\"Ò1À2tññõ9$¯IÁ ß6\JIýÆzL-¤4ë ðµ®B­:gXBð=sý÷GéV¥.Î>q¢ìÅ>áÖÓCåÖöªÖ÷û]¯É¼@¥ÀÆA;®`U]

=lä¶.ÝðhØxÀÈÑ'¬}!7¬1%z®äSæ¼l+â*¼Â¶Dqµµð8ã¶`mGef¢l"'©®NúpØÃÉámà§aåØâ¡üfò¨n´³n_çxÑL4␀×è

cB]]Ý␀Ó¦¢x1p*µ;aè8 måØý.ÀBñG7ÇR'YiË½»À(G?Ö*ÃÔg,ªâõ§¼Á ©×ÆYÒ8|:ÍA¨¶Y/`¡¶þN5H¯Z0ÂT<¦ò"/Aê;C¡Ò␀{ûúÁ"`5CÎirzæ␀öÌ£SFÏ~Æé $'ÑÏvñÂyuña°k þ¦	ê¢ÉÓGýçÖi+i»­÷ò~ÙÖí
 À(Àd¿oü0	3Iáðñª¡«¢;Ou¹		_F¸ºÞøÁK'-^8¯+ÿ␀Ièrøç¼ìPÙk>Çÿ␀Íä¦b l  ìY_Èÿ␀ÿÙ
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        60. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/7.jpg
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (301 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/7.jpg HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?cat=1
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (186 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2022 13:37:46 GMT
Content-Type: image/jpeg
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (19219 bytes) 
          ÿØÿà␀JFIF␀␀␀␀␀␀ÿÛ␀C␀

¯Ð:¦-EÃF:É$òLOyõ<Ågã>£6ÖTVíHË{?ó&óÜÐ:MAÒ¬3±Ü ␀/kZÔÈ³NKfÌÙtßÞ<õ#é¨p¡¸ª~Quyÿ␀Xkõ×®ñ !N¶:␀´¨+ aZÒktË³p/zPÞÒRXÜ@{úUø2ëêêäõ=G½U¢Pów7§ÔF]¾HýÓ¶{Zÿ␀°«?x␀JÂ2°Ò+ ¦ 	;i`1«¯YC¥¶1ó ;-C±4i!␀4Bª´␀UP]Ï19áþ`9g{Oð]Sö]åð¯eâ­¶DÆÇPÔÝÉa¤0À¤dyjS»	ôdÑÕn¡K¯aÐ¼H&%© *ÿ␀ÚæúÎØ¯gï:X«ë(FáþðwIZ¶

SÛ¶6ËæR«RSX, 6	úU^)0[ðµ©½b,àµÃÂÍèN8s®Úèµãà(¼¡\AîÁÞM|Ü 04çÃ4ÏóÁ_5³ó·$i4¾d¸:64j&´`&¢åLôÑLnèðÄæÙ:8DêzÆDB­a¯wG0R©Ü#¹PjT¥UØÜDÌ	TÙ®kì¬îT/W p)Jªáah"ÅZóçë¬%ê×»oËmq4P!%© DÀC@ ÂFuvë`ß»åøÞ.Ì©ZD*×ý}êÂ¶2½Â<<eKUZôDøÐ»ÅÉóù*"ggxÝ)ÚèH½©NØó}

'ô¢nÏSîòx?-ðW¸áQ¥,ý␀«à9¬Gö|àFbÛÞ`ÊYL¦ípP|8×ñ.Ë$(Ö*wöþó ëë}¼Á?·É.cª¬bSáÓèBÞìèÂhkÓX6]JGk{Ôn3ZW/æ%I'␀Nã t ÀñÊ»°ú1D*Æ*Ð	6¡0&ÉÏÈÿ␀x	)"µ²ßè0ü:øÆ~éÆ¤W¨ÎY±FwÖ	iôØ×âFUñyTy´]\h"'Îé7),¡ZBmäq\ykÔ?VdÖWUk@çÜ â¨$*Di[+

}1Ò%UÖð°"8è$U!V3ÆûT°]h+@'A:LãK×@©£UÁ!VhF­DU²¬"©(í␀4SEÁlÁ.ÛG^␀((:wÑÆ>çÐdBóþ²J'¯FHõmÚ5f@» KÙ¢1¢IÂ

 tÑpMÌ£Æ`gC,ob,éD×t)j¯

Á­hðiùuc0S¢-mB;·£4ÍA¨XÊCøx
¨Q`¤Æùvº{þñý)
]_°%öß"_aGÇáh¨B1GäO»ñË?ÿÙ
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        61. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/7.jpg&size=160
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (310 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/7.jpg&size=160 HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?cat=1
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (186 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2022 13:37:46 GMT
Content-Type: image/jpeg
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (19219 bytes) 
          ÿØÿà␀JFIF␀␀␀␀␀␀ÿÛ␀C␀

#	û;ë/õÔ `¿ÅÓ¹ïÑ/]3ÝÀ ûþX'äaø~qeòpj¡9¤£Ç¶"á¥.oQ>ÛÀAJÍ8XÆpø'y­H§'3ÿÚ␀␀␀␀␀␀Éë=¯ú?wÿ␀ÿ␀ÍÅûïÿ␀ÿ␀2ÿ␀Ïþèýïã	Óp¢rÀ£Ö<Òþr+ªÙÓ£ø$Á$¾½ðAíkQb	Ìü:Ù*+×ßÚ®ðZt»º¤Z'9þÀ¨³UmwâQÄ4L¢Oúyp5Í²sKó_Yßo<»WÞ|:BF\þ,}+Hg=ÎZ¢öl5?ÜtP¿¥{ÍBìSÉ¯h	â8þýÐ¿~(öò/ÜÿÄ␀'␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀!1AQaqð¡±ÁÑñ áÿÚ␀?i4@ùé^ÒY)âZ¼NgÓ¯Hî.\¿␀¶²¬{ÌÉ¾ÓÎø_nê>8\(U␀pÛL{ÜIR D+AÒaà-ÀK©Êááztáëùãýó.\¿7G`7\¦:ñ;é7prÛ|(j\¸7¢¯sZl@öé}eÈ±␀Ûyúë	ªuë-DTÍÉà` èo^oÊ[W=

¯Ð:¦-EÃF:É$òLOyõ<Ågã>£6ÖTVíHË{?ó&óÜÐ:MAÒ¬3±Ü ␀/kZÔÈ³NKfÌÙtßÞ<õ#é¨p¡¸ª~Quyÿ␀Xkõ×®ñ !N¶:␀´¨+ aZÒktË³p/zPÞÒRXÜ@{úUø2ëêêäõ=G½U¢Pów7§ÔF]¾HýÓ¶{Zÿ␀°«?x␀JÂ2°Ò+ ¦ 	;i`1«¯YC¥¶1ó ;-C±4i!␀4Bª´␀UP]Ï19áþ`9g{Oð]Sö]åð¯eâ­¶DÆÇPÔÝÉa¤0À¤dyjS»	ôdÑÕn¡K¯aÐ¼H&%© *ÿ␀ÚæúÎØ¯gï:X«ë(FáþðwIZ¶
J¦À°ÀÄ|#©z
~±©¯1.4ÛrbHgÔ#c¥ÄYA`i.#À£5.áï(;«>¶ qÉ§ÃºDÔo)Âà§à@d	ìg ,ÒOÊAÎíÎPIÏð`|=A÷oý`5v\}Ý¼!_Rn*h
R@\é@ãZè/§n81( )â6ù%»¨-ø=>_:Ñ"ÅÙF¦©	°mÆÆ9ÀTu¶X~¨N«
SÛ¶6ËæR«RSX, 6	úU^)0[ðµ©½b,àµÃÂÍèN8s®Úèµãà(¼¡\AîÁÞM|Ü 04çÃ4ÏóÁ_5³ó·$i4¾d¸:64j&´`&¢åLôÑLnèðÄæÙ:8DêzÆDB­a¯wG0R©Ü#¹PjT¥UØÜDÌ	TÙ®kì¬îT/W p)Jªáah"ÅZóçë¬%ê×»oËmq4P!%© DÀC@ ÂFuvë`ß»åøÞ.Ì©ZD*×ý}êÂ¶2½Â<<eKUZôDøÐ»ÅÉóù*"ggxÝ)ÚèH½©NØó}
»
`©]5¥¬å¦=³,º­¨. nÖëX%␀èpÇØ"àÃ:1ÚºDØâ²M/V¿³á´Ãm¸giäÏCû0ñÏ«5 c_¤iõíozßÀ 8b¯z0Ó³$%lc=éÍà¤]0¶1Èï®$²Ò/	]mØ{? A-Ú)W«UUP4Ô=ä@P¢[H,û¹å£DaB!)Ûk)OÒVR»<bãô¡Öe¼´|¶à®n¨BÆ²¯7¹<ää`&écÜ²,Q£ºÈ{(Ô
A]qÃ øENjµÕQÖÈ§©WÅ^ÖÛÐ␀£¦FpÜØMHÍl×g¼ÉBoÈvo@]Îªh
nîÅÍ¡A0␀ÞÖ¢"SûÈá
>¶õ5MBWrN¸@oT±Ý
'ô¢nÏSîòx?-ðW¸áQ¥,ý␀«à9¬Gö|àFbÛÞ`ÊYL¦ípP|8×ñ.Ë$(Ö*wöþó ëë}¼Á?·É.cª¬bSáÓèBÞìèÂhkÓX6]JGk{Ôn3ZW/æ%I'␀Nã t ÀñÊ»°ú1D*Æ*Ð	6¡0&ÉÏÈÿ␀x	)"µ²ßè0ü:øÆ~éÆ¤W¨ÎY±FwÖ	iôØ×âFUñyTy´]\h"'Îé7),¡ZBmäq\ykÔ?VdÖWUk@çÜ â¨$*Di[+
(
}1Ò%UÖð°"8è$U!V3ÆûT°]h+@'A:LãK×@©£UÁ!VhF­DU²¬"©(í␀4SEÁlÁ.ÛG^␀((:wÑÆ>çÐdBóþ²J'¯FHõmÚ5f@» KÙ¢1¢IÂ
Uv«î4aè)ðdï\@	^`T=ÔU1ÍÁ}¾4Ha
ä±¹k#§¡!
¤iÖ@pè,ÜU°"@ Ûè3P
 tÑpMÌ£Æ`gC,ob,éD×t)j¯

Á­hðiùuc0S¢-mB;·£4ÍA¨XÊCøx
¨Q`¤Æùvº{þñý)
]_°%öß"_aGÇáh¨B1GäO»ñË?ÿÙ
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        62. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/signup.php
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (263 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/signup.php HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/login.php
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (200 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2022 13:37:43 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (6033 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
"http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">

<title>signup</title>

<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="headers_rgn" -->

<!-- InstanceEndEditable -->

function MM_reloadPage(init) {  //reloads the window if Nav4 resized
  if (init==true) with (navigator) {if ((appName=="Netscape")&&(parseInt(appVersion)==4)) {
    document.MM_pgW=innerWidth; document.MM_pgH=innerHeight; onresize=MM_reloadPage; }}
  else if (innerWidth!=document.MM_pgW || innerHeight!=document.MM_pgH) location.reload();
}
MM_reloadPage(true);

<div id="content">
<div class="story">
	<h2 id="pageName">Signup new user</h2>
	<h4>Please do not enter real information here.</h4>
	<h4>If you press the submit button you will be transferred to asecured connection.</h4>
	<form name="form1" method="post" action="/secured/newuser.php">
		<table border="0" cellspacing="1" cellpadding="4">
			<tr><td valign="top">Username:</td><td><input type="text" name="uuname" style="width:200px"></td></tr>

<div style="background-color:lightgray;width:100%;text-align:center;font-size:12px;padding:1px">
<p style="padding-left:5%;padding-right:5%"><b>Warning</b>: This is not a real shop. This is an example PHP application, which is intentionally vulnerable to web attacks. It is intended to help you test Acunetix. It also helps you understand how developer errors and bad configuration may let someone break into your website. You can use it to test other tools and your manual hacking skills as well. Tip: Look for potential SQL Injections, Cross-site Scripting (XSS), and Cross-site Request Forgery (CSRF), and more.</p>

          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        63. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/style.css
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (252 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/style.css HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com

          Status line and header section (239 bytes)

          Response body (5482 bytes) 
          body{
	font-family: Arial,sans-serif;
	color: #333333;
	line-height: 1.166;	
	margin: 0px;
	padding: 0px;
}

a:link, a:visited{
	color: #006699;
	text-decoration: none;
}

a:hover {
	text-decoration: underline;
}

h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 {
	font-family: Arial,sans-serif;
	margin: 0px;
	padding: 0px;
}

h1{
 font-family: Verdana,Arial,sans-serif;
 font-size: 120%;
 color: #334d55;
}

h2{
 font-size: 114%;
 color: #006699;
}

h3{
 font-size: 100%;
 color: #334d55;
}

h4{
 font-size: 100%;
 font-weight: normal;
 color: #333333;
}

h5{
 font-size: 100%;
 color: #334d55;
}

 list-style-type: square;
}

ul ul{
 list-style-type: disc;
}

ul ul ul{
 list-style-type: none;
}

label{
 font: bold 100% Arial,sans-serif;
 color: #334d55;
}

	margin: 0;
	padding: 10px 0px;
	border-bottom: 1px solid #cccccc;
	width: 100%;
}

#navBar{
	margin: 0 79% 0 0;
	padding: 0px;
	background-color: #eeeeee;
	border-right: 1px solid #ccc;
	border-bottom: 1px solid #ccc;
}

#content{
  float:right;
	width: 75%;
	margin: 0;
	padding: 0 3% 0 0;
}


/***********************************************/
/*Component Divs                               */
/***********************************************/

#siteName{
	margin: 0px;
	padding: 0px 0px 10px 10px;
}


/*************** #pageName styles **************/

#pageName{
	padding: 0px 0px 10px 10px;
}


/************* #globalNav styles **************/

#globalNav{
color: #cccccc;
padding: 0px 0px 0px 10px;
white-space: nowrap;
}
/* 'nowrap' prevents links from line-wrapping if there are too many to fit in one line
   this will force a horizontal scrollbar if there isn't enough room for all links
   remove rule or change value to 'normal' if you want the links to line-wrap */

#globalNav img{
 display: block;
}

#globalNav a {
	font-size: 90%;
	padding: 0px 4px 0px 0px; 
}


/************* #breadCrumb styles *************/

#breadCrumb{
	font-size: 80%;
	padding: 5px 0px 5px 10px;
}


/************** .feature styles ***************/

.feature{
	padding: 0px 0px 10px 10px;
	font-size: 80%;
}

.feature h3{
	padding: 30px 0px 5px 0px;
	text-align: center;
}

.feature img{
	float: left;
	padding: 0px 10px 0px 0px;
	margin: 0 5px 5px 0;
}
/* adjust margins to change separation between the feature image and text flowing around it */


/************** .story styles *****************/

.story{
	clear: both;
	padding: 10px 0px 0px 10px;
	font-size: 80%;
	background-color:#FFFFFF;
}

.story p{
	padding: 0px 0px 10px 0px;
	background-color:#FFFFFF;
}

/************* #siteInfo styles ***************/

#siteInfo{
	clear: both;
	border: 1px solid #cccccc;
	font-size: 75%;
	color: #cccccc;
	padding: 10px 10px 10px 10px;
	margin-top: -1px;
}
/* negative top margin pulls siteinfo up so its top border overlaps (and thus lines up with)
	the bottom border of the navBar in cases where they "touch" */

#siteInfo img{
	padding: 4px 4px 4px 0px;
	vertical-align: middle;
}


/************* #search styles ***************/

#search{
	padding: 5px 0px 5px 10px;
	border-bottom: 1px solid #cccccc;
	font-size: 90%;
}

#search form{
 margin: 0px;
 padding: 0px;
}

#search label{
	display: block;
	margin: 0px;
	padding: 0px;
}


/*********** #navBar link styles ***********/

#navBar ul a:link, #navBar ul a:visited {display: block;}
#navBar ul {list-style: none; margin: 0; padding: 0;}

/* hack to fix IE/Win's broken rendering of block-level anchors in lists */
#navBar li {border-bottom: 1px solid #EEE;}

/* fix for browsers that don't need the hack */
html>body #navBar li {border-bottom: none;}


/*********** #sectionLinks styles ***********/

#sectionLinks{
	position: relative;
	margin: 0px;
	padding: 0px;
	border-bottom: 1px solid #cccccc;
	font-size: 90%;
}

#sectionLinks h3{
	padding: 10px 0px 2px 10px;
}

#sectionLinks a:link{
	padding: 2px 0px 2px 10px;
	border-top: 1px solid #cccccc;
	width: 100%;
  voice-family: "\"}\""; 
  voice-family:inherit;
	width: auto;
}

#sectionLinks a:visited{
	border-top: 1px solid #cccccc;
	padding: 2px 0px 2px 10px;
}

#sectionLinks a:hover{
	border-top: 1px solid #cccccc;
	background-color: #dddddd;
	padding: 2px 0px 2px 10px;
}

.relatedLinks{
	margin: 0px;
	padding: 0px 0px 10px 10px;
	font-size: 90%;
}

.relatedLinks h3{
	padding: 10px 0px 2px 0px;
}

	padding: 0px 10px 0px 0px;

	font-size:10px;

	background-color:#F5F5F5;
}

	border-style:ridge;

}

}

	background-color:#FFFFFF;
}
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        64. POST http://testphp.vulnweb.com/cart.php
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (339 bytes) 
          POST http://testphp.vulnweb.com/cart.php HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/product.php?pic=2
Content-Length: 19
          Request body (19 bytes) 
          price=800&addcart=2
          Response
          Status line and header section (200 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0

  Acunetix Ltd

<br> 
<div style="background-color:lightgray;width:100%;text-align:center;font-size:12px;padding:1px">
<p style="padding-left:5%;padding-right:5%"><b>Warning</b>: This is not a real shop. This is an example PHP application, which is intentionally vulnerable to web attacks. It is intended to help you test Acunetix. It also helps you understand how developer errors and bad configuration may let someone break into your website. You can use it to test other tools and your manual hacking skills as well. Tip: Look for potential SQL Injections, Cross-site Scripting (XSS), and Cross-site Request Forgery (CSRF), and more.</p>
</div>
</div>
</body>
<!-- InstanceEnd --></html>
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        65. POST http://testphp.vulnweb.com/guestbook.php
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (340 bytes) 
          POST http://testphp.vulnweb.com/guestbook.php HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/guestbook.php
Content-Length: 33
          Request body (33 bytes) 
          name=ZAP&text=&submit=add+message
          Response
          Status line and header section (200 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2022 13:37:43 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (5393 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
"http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><!-- InstanceBegin template="/Templates/main_dynamic_template.dwt.php" codeOutsideHTMLIsLocked="false" -->
<head>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-2">

<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="document_title_rgn" -->
<title>guestbook</title>
<!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
<link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css" type="text/css">
<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="headers_rgn" -->
<!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
<script language="JavaScript" type="text/JavaScript">

    document.MM_pgW=innerWidth; document.MM_pgH=innerHeight; onresize=MM_reloadPage; }}
  else if (innerWidth!=document.MM_pgW || innerHeight!=document.MM_pgH) location.reload();

          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        66. POST http://testphp.vulnweb.com/search.php?test=query
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

<p style="padding-left:5%;padding-right:5%"><b>Warning</b>: This is not a real shop. This is an example PHP application, which is intentionally vulnerable to web attacks. It is intended to help you test Acunetix. It also helps you understand how developer errors and bad configuration may let someone break into your website. <!-- InstanceEnd --></html>
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        67. POST http://testphp.vulnweb.com/secured/newuser.php
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (343 bytes) 
          POST http://testphp.vulnweb.com/secured/newuser.php HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/signup.php
Content-Length: 96
          Request body (96 bytes) 
          uuname=ZAP&upass=ZAP&upass2=ZAP&urname=ZAP&ucc=ZAP&uemail=ZAP&uphone=ZAP&uaddress=&signup=signup
          Response
          Status line and header section (200 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2022 13:37:47 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (733 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html>
<head>
<title>add new user</title>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<link href="style.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css">
</head>
<body>
<div id="masthead"> 
  <h1 id="siteName">ACUNETIX ART</h1> 
</div>
<div id="content">
	<p>You have been introduced to our database with the above informations:</p><ul><li>Username: ZAP</li><li>Password: ZAP</li><li>Name: ZAP</li><li>Address: </li><li>E-Mail: ZAP</li><li>Phone number: ZAP</li><li>Credit card: ZAP</li></ul><p>Now you can login from <a href='http://testphp.vulnweb.com/login.php'>here.</p></div>
</body>
</html>
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
      3. 缺少反CSRF令牌 (40)
        1. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A01
          • WSTG-v42-SESS-05
          • OWASP_2017_A05
          Alert description

          在提交的HTML表单中中找不到反CSRF令牌。

          A cross-site request forgery is an attack that involves forcing a victim to send an HTTP request to a target destination without their knowledge or intent in order to perform an action as the victim. The underlying cause is application functionality using predictable URL/form actions in a repeatable way. The nature of the attack is that CSRF exploits the trust that a web site has for a user. By contrast, cross-site scripting (XSS) exploits the trust that a user has for a web site. Like XSS, CSRF attacks are not necessarily cross-site, but they can be. Cross-site request forgery is also known as CSRF, XSRF, one-click attack, session riding, confused deputy, and sea surf.

          CSRF attacks are effective in a number of situations, including:

          * The victim has an active session on the target site.

          * The victim is authenticated via HTTP auth on the target site.

          * The victim is on the same local network as the target site.

          CSRF has primarily been used to perform an action against a target site using the victim's privileges, but recent techniques have been discovered to disclose information by gaining access to the response. The risk of information disclosure is dramatically increased when the target site is vulnerable to XSS, because XSS can be used as a platform for CSRF, allowing the attack to operate within the bounds of the same-origin policy.
          Other info

          No known Anti-CSRF token [anticsrf, CSRFToken, __RequestVerificationToken, csrfmiddlewaretoken, authenticity_token, OWASP_CSRFTOKEN, anoncsrf, csrf_token, _csrf, _csrfSecret, __csrf_magic, CSRF, _token, _csrf_token] was found in the following HTML form: [Form 1: "goButton" "searchFor" ].
          Request
          Request line and header section (205 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (200 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0

Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (4958 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
"http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">

<div id="siteInfo">  <a href="http://www.acunetix.com">About Us</a> | <a href="privacy.php">Privacy Policy</a> | <a href="mailto:wvs@acunetix.com">Contact Us</a> | <a href="/Mod_Rewrite_Shop/">Shop</a> | <a href="/hpp/">HTTP Parameter Pollution</a> | &copy;2019

<br> 
<div style="background-color:lightgray;width:100%;text-align:center;font-size:12px;padding:1px">
<p style="padding-left:5%;padding-right:5%"><b>Warning</b>: This is not a real shop. This is an example PHP application, which is intentionally vulnerable to web attacks. It is intended to help you test Acunetix. It also helps you understand how developer errors and bad configuration may let someone break into your website. You can use it to test other tools and your manual hacking skills as well. Tip: Look for potential SQL Injections, Cross-site Scripting (XSS), and Cross-site Request Forgery (CSRF), and more.</p>
</div>
</div>
</body>
<!-- InstanceEnd --></html>
          Evidence 
          <form action="search.php?test=query" method="post">
          Solution

          フェーズ： アーキテクチャと設計

          同脆弱性を引き起こさせない、あるいは容易に回避可能な精査されたライブラリ、あるいはフレームワークを使用してください。

          For example, use anti-CSRF packages such as the OWASP CSRFGuard.

          Phase: Implementation

          Ensure that your application is free of cross-site scripting issues, because most CSRF defenses can be bypassed using attacker-controlled script.

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Generate a unique nonce for each form, place the nonce into the form, and verify the nonce upon receipt of the form. Be sure that the nonce is not predictable (CWE-330).

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Identify especially dangerous operations. When the user performs a dangerous operation, send a separate confirmation request to ensure that the user intended to perform that operation.

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Use the ESAPI Session Management control.

          This control includes a component for CSRF.

          Do not use the GET method for any request that triggers a state change.

          Phase: Implementation

          Check the HTTP Referer header to see if the request originated from an expected page. This could break legitimate functionality, because users or proxies may have disabled sending the Referer for privacy reasons.
        2. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/artists.php
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A01
          • WSTG-v42-SESS-05
          • OWASP_2017_A05
          Alert description

          在提交的HTML表单中中找不到反CSRF令牌。

          A cross-site request forgery is an attack that involves forcing a victim to send an HTTP request to a target destination without their knowledge or intent in order to perform an action as the victim. The underlying cause is application functionality using predictable URL/form actions in a repeatable way. The nature of the attack is that CSRF exploits the trust that a web site has for a user. By contrast, cross-site scripting (XSS) exploits the trust that a user has for a web site. Like XSS, CSRF attacks are not necessarily cross-site, but they can be. Cross-site request forgery is also known as CSRF, XSRF, one-click attack, session riding, confused deputy, and sea surf.

          CSRF attacks are effective in a number of situations, including:

          * The victim has an active session on the target site.

          * The victim is authenticated via HTTP auth on the target site.

          * The victim is on the same local network as the target site.

          CSRF has primarily been used to perform an action against a target site using the victim's privileges, but recent techniques have been discovered to disclose information by gaining access to the response. The risk of information disclosure is dramatically increased when the target site is vulnerable to XSS, because XSS can be used as a platform for CSRF, allowing the attack to operate within the bounds of the same-origin policy.
          Other info

          No known Anti-CSRF token [anticsrf, CSRFToken, __RequestVerificationToken, csrfmiddlewaretoken, authenticity_token, OWASP_CSRFTOKEN, anoncsrf, csrf_token, _csrf, _csrfSecret, __csrf_magic, CSRF, _token, _csrf_token] was found in the following HTML form: [Form 1: "goButton" "searchFor" ].

          Solution

          フェーズ： アーキテクチャと設計

          同脆弱性を引き起こさせない、あるいは容易に回避可能な精査されたライブラリ、あるいはフレームワークを使用してください。

          For example, use anti-CSRF packages such as the OWASP CSRFGuard.

          Phase: Implementation

          Ensure that your application is free of cross-site scripting issues, because most CSRF defenses can be bypassed using attacker-controlled script.

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Generate a unique nonce for each form, place the nonce into the form, and verify the nonce upon receipt of the form. Be sure that the nonce is not predictable (CWE-330).

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Identify especially dangerous operations. When the user performs a dangerous operation, send a separate confirmation request to ensure that the user intended to perform that operation.

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Use the ESAPI Session Management control.

          This control includes a component for CSRF.

          Do not use the GET method for any request that triggers a state change.

          Phase: Implementation

          Check the HTTP Referer header to see if the request originated from an expected page. This could break legitimate functionality, because users or proxies may have disabled sending the Referer for privacy reasons.
        3. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/artists.php?artist=1
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A01
          • WSTG-v42-SESS-05
          • OWASP_2017_A05
          Alert description

          在提交的HTML表单中中找不到反CSRF令牌。

          A cross-site request forgery is an attack that involves forcing a victim to send an HTTP request to a target destination without their knowledge or intent in order to perform an action as the victim. The underlying cause is application functionality using predictable URL/form actions in a repeatable way. The nature of the attack is that CSRF exploits the trust that a web site has for a user. By contrast, cross-site scripting (XSS) exploits the trust that a user has for a web site. Like XSS, CSRF attacks are not necessarily cross-site, but they can be. Cross-site request forgery is also known as CSRF, XSRF, one-click attack, session riding, confused deputy, and sea surf.

          CSRF attacks are effective in a number of situations, including:

          * The victim has an active session on the target site.

          * The victim is authenticated via HTTP auth on the target site.

          * The victim is on the same local network as the target site.

          CSRF has primarily been used to perform an action against a target site using the victim's privileges, but recent techniques have been discovered to disclose information by gaining access to the response. The risk of information disclosure is dramatically increased when the target site is vulnerable to XSS, because XSS can be used as a platform for CSRF, allowing the attack to operate within the bounds of the same-origin policy.

          No known Anti-CSRF token [anticsrf, CSRFToken, __RequestVerificationToken, csrfmiddlewaretoken, authenticity_token, OWASP_CSRFTOKEN, anoncsrf, csrf_token, _csrf, _csrfSecret, __csrf_magic, CSRF, _token, _csrf_token] was found in the following HTML form: [Form 1: "goButton" "searchFor" ].

<div id="content">
	<h2 id='pageName'>artist: r4w8173</h2><div class='story'><p><p>
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetuer adipiscing elit. Donec molestie.
    Sed aliquam sem ut arcu. Phasellus sollicitudin. Vestibulum condimentum facilisis
    nulla. In hac habitasse platea dictumst. Nulla nonummy. Cras quis libero.
    Cras venenatis. Aliquam posuere lobortis pede. Nullam fringilla urna id leo.
    Praesent aliquet pretium erat. Praesent non odio. Pellentesque a magna a
    mauris vulputate lacinia. Aenean viverra. Class aptent taciti sociosqu ad
    litora torquent per conubia nostra, per inceptos hymenaeos. Aliquam lacus.
    Mauris magna eros, semper a, tempor et, rutrum et, tortor.
</p>
<p>
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetuer adipiscing elit. Donec molestie.
    Sed aliquam sem ut arcu. Phasellus sollicitudin. Vestibulum condimentum facilisis
    nulla. In hac habitasse platea dictumst. Nulla nonummy. Cras quis libero.
    Cras venenatis. Aliquam posuere lobortis pede. Nullam fringilla urna id leo.
    Praesent aliquet pretium erat. Praesent non odio. Pellentesque a magna a
    mauris vulputate lacinia. Aenean viverra. Class aptent taciti sociosqu ad
    litora torquent per conubia nostra, per inceptos hymenaeos. Aliquam lacus.
    Mauris magna eros, semper a, tempor et, rutrum et, tortor.

<div id="siteInfo">  <a href="http://www.acunetix.com">About Us</a> | <a href="privacy.php">Privacy Policy</a> | <a href="mailto:wvs@acunetix.com">Contact Us</a> | &copy;2019
  Acunetix Ltd

<br> 
<div style="background-color:lightgray;width:100%;text-align:center;font-size:12px;padding:1px">
<p style="padding-left:5%;padding-right:5%"><b>Warning</b>: This is not a real shop. This is an example PHP application, which is intentionally vulnerable to web attacks. It is intended to help you test Acunetix. It also helps you understand how developer errors and bad configuration may let someone break into your website. You can use it to test other tools and your manual hacking skills as well. Tip: Look for potential SQL Injections, Cross-site Scripting (XSS), and Cross-site Request Forgery (CSRF), and more.</p>
</div>
</div>
</body>
<!-- InstanceEnd --></html>
          Evidence 
          <form action="search.php?test=query" method="post">
          Solution

          フェーズ： アーキテクチャと設計

          同脆弱性を引き起こさせない、あるいは容易に回避可能な精査されたライブラリ、あるいはフレームワークを使用してください。

          For example, use anti-CSRF packages such as the OWASP CSRFGuard.

          Phase: Implementation

          Ensure that your application is free of cross-site scripting issues, because most CSRF defenses can be bypassed using attacker-controlled script.

          Phase: Architecture and Design

          Generate a unique nonce for each form, place the nonce into the form, and verify the nonce upon receipt of the form. Be sure that the nonce is not predictable (CWE-330).

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Identify especially dangerous operations. When the user performs a dangerous operation, send a separate confirmation request to ensure that the user intended to perform that operation.

          Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

          Use the ESAPI Session Management control.

          This control includes a component for CSRF.

          Do not use the GET method for any request that triggers a state change.

          Phase: Implementation

          Check the HTTP Referer header to see if the request originated from an expected page. This could break legitimate functionality, because users or proxies may have disabled sending the Referer for privacy reasons.
        4. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/artists.php?artist=2
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A01
          • WSTG-v42-SESS-05
          • OWASP_2017_A05
          Alert description

          在提交的HTML表单中中找不到反CSRF令牌。

          A cross-site request forgery is an attack that involves forcing a victim to send an HTTP request to a target destination without their knowledge or intent in order to perform an action as the victim. The underlying cause is application functionality using predictable URL/form actions in a repeatable way. The nature of the attack is that CSRF exploits the trust that a web site has for a user. By contrast, cross-site scripting (XSS) exploits the trust that a user has for a web site. Like XSS, CSRF attacks are not necessarily cross-site, but they can be. Cross-site request forgery is also known as CSRF, XSRF, one-click attack, session riding, confused deputy, and sea surf.

          CSRF attacks are effective in a number of situations, including:

          * The victim has an active session on the target site.

          * The victim is authenticated via HTTP auth on the target site.

          * The victim is on the same local network as the target site.

          CSRF has primarily been used to perform an action against a target site using the victim's privileges, but recent techniques have been discovered to disclose information by gaining access to the response. The risk of information disclosure is dramatically increased when the target site is vulnerable to XSS, because XSS can be used as a platform for CSRF, allowing the attack to operate within the bounds of the same-origin policy.
          Other info

          No known Anti-CSRF token [anticsrf, CSRFToken, __RequestVerificationToken, csrfmiddlewaretoken, authenticity_token, OWASP_CSRFTOKEN, anoncsrf, csrf_token, _csrf, _csrfSecret, __csrf_magic, CSRF, _token, _csrf_token] was found in the following HTML form: [Form 1: "goButton" "searchFor" ].
          Request
          Request line and header section (275 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/artists.php?artist=2 HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/artists.php
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (200 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2022 13:37:43 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (6193 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
"http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">

<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="headers_rgn" -->

  if (init==true) with (navigator) {if ((appName=="Netscape")&&(parseInt(appVersion)==4)) {
    document.MM_pgW=innerWidth; document.MM_pgH=innerHeight; onresize=MM_reloadPage; }}
  else if (innerWidth!=document.MM_pgW || innerHeight!=document.MM_pgH) location.reload();
}
